data.text: Contents

Dress code for all uniformed and non-uniformed staff entering clinical areas - bare below the elbows ................................................................................................................. 8
Introduction
This policy sets out the expectations of the Trust and the necessity for all staff to:
Convey a professional and efficient image of the Trust
Promote a sense of pride and organisational identity
Install confidence for patients, their carers, relatives and visitors
Enable easily identifiable staff structure/demarcation of uniformed staff
Contribute towards, and support infection prevention and control
Comply with Health and Safety legislation
Contribute towards Privacy and Dignity
Minimise the risk of cross infection.
The Trust recognises the diversity of cultures, religions and disabilities of its employees and staff.

The policy is based on the principles and guidelines within the Sex Discrimination Act 1975, Religious or Belief Regulations 2003, and the Disability Discrimination Act 2005, Uniforms and workwear: Guidance on uniform and workwear policies for NHS employers, DH  and also the rights of individuals to express themselves freely. The Trust reserves the right to review and amend this policy at any time through the Trust's consultation and communication processes, following changes to legislation or guidelines.

Non – compliance to this policy by any member of staff may result in disciplinary action under the Trust's Policy for handling Disciplinary Issues (PP6) being instigated which could lead to dismissal. Staff have a right to appeal against any decision taken under the Trust Policy for Handling Disciplinary issues (PP6) in line with the usual Appeal process.
Scope
The purpose of this document is:

Purpose 1 – application to all staff, including those with honorary contracts, sub- contractors, agency workers, and students when working on Trust premises. It applies to both uniformed and non-uniformed staff groups.

Purpose 2 - This policy does not comprehensively cover the wearing of personal protective clothing and equipment. For more information refer to IC 027 Standard Precaution Policy (available on the Trust Intranet). Uniforms and workwear are not personal protective clothing and items like disposable plastic aprons and gowns must be used to protect uniforms and work clothing from contamination during patient care activities.
Application of standard infection control precautions following a risk assessment is key to protecting patients and staff from cross contamination with pathogenic organisms.
Definitions

table_items.text: Below the elbow joint should be free from clothes and jewellery. Items with long sleeves are either to be removed (where appropriate) or long sleeves rolled up

For the purpose of this policy, encompasses conducting any ward based clinical care. e.g. Ward rounds, ad hoc visits, procedures or investigations. It also includes work in an outpatient environment whenever a patient is examined.
For the purpose of this policy, those procedures where the staff have direct patient contact or are undertaking invasive procedures.

Activity involving direct contact with patients and their close environment. This includes examining patients, wound care, collecting samples for testing and having contact with the patient's immediate surroundings including bed, table, locker, charts etc.
The practice of physically decontaminating the hands using the most appropriate method and product as determined by assessment of risk
The practice of physically decontaminating hands using the most appropriate method and product as deemed by assessment of risk

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
The Chief Executive Officer as accounting officer is responsible for the quality and safety of the services provided by the Trust

The Executive Directors are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this policy in line with other related policies such as infection control, health and safety and patient safety policies. They are exemplar role models at Executive level.
The Site Leadership teams are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this policy on each individual site. They are exemplar role models at site level.
Clinical Directors and Senior Managers

Clinical Directors and senior Managers are responsible for the implementation and control measures put in place to reduce risks and that staff are aware of current health and safety legislation and infection control policies. They are exemplar role models.
Consultants and Senior Clinicians/ Heads of Nursing Midwifery/Matrons /Service Managers/Ward and Department Managers/Clinical Leads

Managers and Clinical Leads are responsible for ensuring that this policy is adhered to at all times in respect of those staff they are responsible for, and for challenging blatant non-compliance by bringing it to the attention of the individual, and where necessary their line manager. They are an exemplar role model.

The Health and Safety Manager is responsible for providing specialist advice on the current Health and Safety regulations in relation to uniforms and personal protective equipment (PPE) clothing and has the authority to implement immediate remedial action in an unsafe situation, wherever reasonably practicable. They are an exemplar role mode.

All employees and honorary staff whether uniformed or non-uniformed are responsible for following standards of uniform/dress and appearance as set out in this policy, and should understand how this policy relates to their working environment, health & safety, infection control, their particular role and duties, during the course of their employment, and honorary duties carried out within the Trust.

All employees are supplied with a Trust identity badge that must be worn and visible at all times when on duty or acting in an official capacity representing the Trust. All Trust employees with Honorary Trust contracts, visiting clinical staff and contractors must also wear ID badges.

All staff are required to comply with the principles of the Dress Code, and where appropriate, to the requirements of the Uniform Policy. Failure to adhere to the Trust's standards of dress and appearance may constitute misconduct and result in formal disciplinary proceedings by respective employers.
All clothing (including uniforms) worn, must be comfortable for the wearer, allow freedom of movement and be of appropriate size and length.

When attending study days, internal and external to the Trust, clothing must be respectable, inoffensive and in keeping with the principles of the Trusts Dress Code. Consideration must be given to the nature of the study session to ensure comfort and practicability, i.e. Manual Handling or Basic Life support training.
Dress code for all staff – the principles

Staff should at all times bear in mind the importance of presenting a professional and positive image when selecting clothing to be worn at work, the Dress Code applies to all staff, including those who are:
not required to wear uniforms or standardised clothing,
required to wear uniform or standardised clothing
required to wear protective clothing
The Trust defines the Dress Code as ‘Smart' and the following items of clothing are examples of excluded items of clothing that should not be worn and  this is not an exhaustive list:
Clothing made of Denim, including jeans, trousers, skirts, jackets, waistcoats and shirts)
Combat patterned/designed clothing, unless as part of an approved uniform.
Sportswear, for example shorts, track suits, baseball caps
Casual tee shirts logo/slogan covered or printed except Polo shirts with approved Trust logo as identified in this policy.
Very short (more than few centimetres above the knee) skirts and shorts.
Very tight fitting and/or skimpy and/or transparent clothing,
Low cut neck lines, exposed chest/midriffs/hips, backs.
Flip flops and other similar shoe wear that does not effectively cover and protect the feet must not be worn due to the inherent risk of injury, unless as part of an approved uniform.
Excessive jewellery
Visible jewellery and piercing should be discreet and not likely to cause offence or a health and safety hazard.

Tattoos are not allowed if they could cause provocation or offence to other staff, patients and the public, unacceptable tattoos include those that are or are liable to be perceived as having unacceptable attitudes towards women, minority groups or any other section of the community; or that they are aligned with a particular group which could give offence. Staff that display tattoos that are considered to be rude, lewd, crude, racist, sexist, sectarian, homophobic, violent or intimidating should be referred to their line manager to consider actions under the disciplinary policy.
Lanyards should be fabric, washable and no diamante and comply with the same principles as laid out for Tattoos and should not cause offense.

Hair should be kept neat and tidy and clean. If hair is dyed, consideration to a professional appearance should be made, unprofessional colours would include neon colours or multiple colours, staff should seek advice from their line manager if they are unsure if a colour would be deemed professional. Headscarves and other hair decorations should be in keeping with the general principles of this policy, i.e. of subtle colour.
Beards and moustaches should be short and neatly trimmed, unless this reflects the individual's religion where it should be tidy with consideration to being able to wear appropriate fitted PPE

Where a head scarf or a veil is worn, as part of religious observance employees must ensure that the flow of the garment does not interfere with work practice and is a plain, dark colour if wearing with a uniform. This must be changed on a daily basis to minimize cross infection.

In addition to the Trust identity name badge (and/ or another identity badge i.e. agency worker or student) a maximum of 2 other badges maybe worn and these must be professional or linked to NHS initiatives.

Any employee who has a need for special consideration to be given to their appropriate clothing due to having a disability should bring this to the attention of their line manager, seeking support and guidance from Occupational Health, Infection Prevention and Control team and Human Resources as necessary
Dress code for all uniformed and non-uniformed staff entering
clinical areas - bare below the elbows
All staff must adhere to the Bare Below the elbow (BBE) standard on entering a clinical environment or patient area.

The Bare Below the Elbow (BBE) standard is a crucial factor related to infection prevention and control and patient confidence. Effective hand hygiene requires exposing the wrists and forearms and watches and/or other jewellery to be removed with the exception of one plain finger band.
If the member of staff in the clinical area has no direct patient contact and is only visiting a clinical area the above applies however, nail varnish and nail extensions are permitted.
Uniform policy – all clinical staff

There are some members of staff that are required to wear uniforms or light weight uniform (smart scrubs) to fulfil their role or work in their own clothing in the clinical area this section of the policy refers to those staff and includes:
Nursing and Midwifery staff and their teams
Medical staff
Allied Health Professionals and their teams to include for example (but not exclusively), Radiographers, Physiotherapists and Occupational therapists.
Healthcare Scientists
Support staff i.e. housekeeper
Students undertaking clinical placement and those on work experience.
Bank and Agency nursing staff
Chaplains
All staff must keep their clothing or uniform clean and in good order.

With the exception of undertaking essential work related duties, e.g. home visits - Staff are permitted to travel to work by private transport in uniform with an outer garment (e.g. a coat) that covers their Tunic or dress, and staff should change into their own clothes to travel home from work. Staff must not travel to or from work on public transport in their uniform.

Staff MUST NOT wear their uniform for any activity other than the post for which they are employed. They must not engage in personal or private activities outside of the Trust whilst wearing a Trust identifiable uniform, including smoking, vaping and shopping.

All staff that are required to wear a uniform will be provided with 3 complete uniforms when commencing work in the Trust which is sufficient to wear a clean uniform every day. New uniforms should be requested when they become unusable.
Uniforms and clothing worn at work should be washed on the hottest temperature suitable for the fabric
A plain t-shirt under the Uniform tunic may be worn, white for light coloured uniforms blue/black for dark uniforms.

Buckles and Trust approved belts may be worn by registered staff and must be thoroughly washed with hot soapy water at least weekly and when contamination/soiling has occurred. Belts with buckles must be removed when carrying out direct patient care to allow for freedom of movement and to prevent injury to oneself or patients/colleagues.

Hair must be kept neat and tidy and long hair below the collar must be neatly and securely fastened up, relatively close to the head, long ponytails are not allowed. Hair accessories should be plain in colour and discreet
Cosmetics maybe worn in moderation and should be appropriate to the work environment.
Some jewellery is permitted in the clinical environment but should be discrete,
You can wear
one plain finger band
Discreet stud earrings
Discreet plain facial studs
With the exception of religious reasons you must not wear:
Bracelets (unless medical) (if worn for religious reasons they may be pushed up the arm and taped to enable effective clinical hand washing/decontamination)
Any item that would conflict with Personal protection equipment
Wrist watches, fit bits or similar must not be worn, fob watches may be worn.

Nail varnish, false or gel nails must not be worn as they pose a risk of infection (Mauback 2003, Lin et al 2003) and fingernails must be kept short to prevent harm to patients, no longer than to the end of the fingers.
If/when worn, dresses must be measured to below the knee.

Hosiery must be worn according to the specific uniform stipulated for the staff group and must be plain. Hosiery may be removed in hot weather following agreement with the staff member's line manager.
Only full length trousers may be worn.

Black fully closed shoes or trainers that are fluid repellent, able to be securely fastened, rubber soled, low heeled and do not generate noise when walking must be worn appropriate to the specific uniform stipulated for the staff group.

Trust approved cardigans/fleeces must be plain without decoration; exception will be for Trust approved logos. They must not be worn when direct patient care/contact is being performed, or when carrying out general duties within clinical areas. In some corridors and waiting rooms adjacent to clinical areas, cardigans/fleeces may be worn; however, the Bare Below the Elbows principle still must apply.

Exposure of the forearms is not acceptable in some religions. The Department of Health policy-makers and external experts in infection prevention and multi- faith representatives prepared a list of recommendations (DoH 2010) to ensure that local dress code policies are sensitive to the obligations of faith groups whilst maintaining equivalent standards of hygiene.
The advice is as follows:

Uniforms may include provision for sleeves that can be full length when staff are not engaged in direct patient care activity. The definition of direct patient care is detailed at Appendix 3. The advice is as follows:

Uniforms can have three-quarter length sleeves. Any full or three-quarter length sleeves must not be loose or dangling. They must be able to be rolled or pulled back and kept securely in place during hand-washing and direct patient care activity.
Disposable over-sleeves, elasticated at the elbow and wrist, may be used but must be put on and discarded in exactly the same way as disposable gloves.
Strict procedures for washing hands and wrists must still be observed.
Use of hand disinfection gels containing synthetic alcohol does not fall within the Muslim prohibition against natural alcohol (from fermented fruit or grain).
Cross Site Working
Staff who wear a uniform and whose role involves cross site working only needs to change out of their uniform if they have been working within the clinical area
Uniform policy – the wearing of ‘theatre scrubs'
A separate document will be in place for the wearing of theatre scrubs.
Uniform policy and dress code – on call out of hours

It is acknowledged that staff attending the hospital urgently, out of hours, may not be able to comply fully with the principles of the Dress Code. Every attempt, however, should be made to comply with the policy.
Other standards of dress
Staff may request to wear alternative clothing on occasions, for example:
supporting national and local campaigns for fund raising, raising awareness
‘high days' and ‘holidays', remembrance and celebration.
Such requests should be made in the first instance to the Divisional Triumvirate, discussed with the Communications Department, and authorisation sought from the Executive Team.
Staff are expected to maintain a professional image at all times regardless of work area and dispensation from any aspect of this policy must be sought from their line manager.
Training Requirements
Training on effective Hand Hygiene is mandatory for all members of staff.
Monitoring and Audit
Outlined  below  is  the  Trust's  process  of  monitoring  compliance  with,  and  the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectivenes s being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monito ring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
with Hand Hygiene and bare below the elbow

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the infection prevention and control committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform all staff groups via divisional leads of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
References

Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (2002). Guidance for hand Hygiene in HealthCare Settings Recommendations of the Healthcare Infection Control Practices Advisory Committee and the HICPAC/SHEA/APIC/IDSA hand Hygiene Task Force.
Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report. October 25, Vol 51, No. RR-16 Department of Health (2006)
The Health Act 2006 Code of Practice for the Prevention and Control of Healthcare Associated Infections. Revised July 2015.
Department of Health (2007) Uniforms and Workwear. An evidence base for developing local policy.

Department of Health (2010) uniforms and workwear: Guidance on uniform and workwear policies for NHS employers Nursing and Midwifery Council (2004) Code of professional conduct www.nmc-uk.org.uk ICTAP Infection Control – Training Module, Reducing Cross Infection, Handwashing, Version 3.0 Copyright 1998 WB Saunders ICTAP Infection Control – Hospital Wide Policies, Other Hospital-Wide Policies, Universal (standard) precautions Version 3.0 Copyright 1998 WB Saunders Pratt RJ, Pellowe, CM, Wilson JA et al (2007) epic2: National Evidence-Based Guidelines for Preventing Healthcare-Associated Infections in NHS Hospitals in England.

Journal of Hospital Infection Vol 65 Supp1. Wilson JA, Loveday HP, Hoffman PN, Pratt RJ (2007) Uniform: an evidence review of the microbiological significance of uniforms and uniform policy in the prevention and control of healthcare-associated infections.
Report to the Department of Health (England) Journal of Hospital Infection 66, 301- 307 Woodhead K, Taylor EW, Bannister G et al (2001) Behaviours and rituals in the operating theatre.

A report from the hospital Infection Society Working Group on Infection Control in the Operating Theatres. World Alliance for Patient Safety (2007) WHO guidelines on hand hygiene in health care (advanced draft)
